results.title: Metformin is Associated with Decreased 30-Day Mortality Among Nursing Home Residents Infected with SARS-CoV2
results.text_hl: @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@Metformin@@@ is Associated with Decreased 30-Day @DISEASE_Death @DISEASE_MESH:D003643 @@@Mortality@@@ Among Nursing Home Residents Infected with @<m>DISEASE_Severe_Acute_Respiratory_Syndrome</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D045169 @@@SARS-CoV2@@@

citations.NLM: Lally MA, Tsoukas P, Halladay CW, O'Neill E, Gravenstein S, Rudolph JL. Metformin is Associated with Decreased 30-Day Mortality Among Nursing Home Residents Infected with SARS-CoV2 J Am Med Dir Assoc. 2021 Jan;22(1):193-198. PMID: 33232684
citations.BibTeX: @article{33232684, title={Metformin is Associated with Decreased 30-Day Mortality Among Nursing Home Residents Infected with SARS-CoV2}, author={Lally MA and Tsoukas P and Halladay CW and O'Neill E and Gravenstein S and Rudolph JL}, journal={J Am Med Dir Assoc}, volume={22}, number={1}, pages={193-198}}

results.title: Diabetes, Metformin and the Clinical Course of Covid-19: Outcomes, Mechanisms and Suggestions on the Therapeutic Use of Metformin
results.text_hl: Studies on the effects of @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@ on outcomes in people infected with @DISEASE_COVID_19 @DISEASE_MESH:D000086382 @@@Covid-19@@@ were identified by searching PubMed using the following search string: @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@ AND (@DISEASE_COVID_19 @DISEASE_MESH:D000086382 @@@covid@@@ [ti] OR @DISEASE_COVID_19 @DISEASE_MESH:D000086382 @@@covid-19@@@ [ti] OR @DISEASE_COVID_19 @DISEASE_MESH:D000086382 @@@covid19@@@ [ti] OR @DISEASE_Coronavirus_Infections @DISEASE_MESH:D018352 @@@coronavirus@@@ [ti] OR @<m>DISEASE_Severe_Acute_Respiratory_Syndrome</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D045169 @@@SARS-Cov2@@@ [ti]), and @DISEASE_Diabetes_Mellitus @DISEASE_MESH:D003920 @@@diabetes@@@ AND (@DISEASE_COVID_19 @DISEASE_MESH:D000086382 @@@covid@@@ OR @DISEASE_COVID_19 @DISEASE_MESH:D000086382 @@@covid-19@@@ OR @DISEASE_COVID_19 @DISEASE_MESH:D000086382 @@@covid19@@@ OR @DISEASE_Coronavirus_Infections @DISEASE_MESH:D018352 @@@coronavirus@@@ [ti] OR @<m>DISEASE_Severe_Acute_Respiratory_Syndrome</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D045169 @@@SARS-Cov2@@@ [ti]); the second search was limited to "Clinical Study, Clinical Trial, Controlled Clinical Trial, Meta-Analysis, Observational Study, Randomized Controlled Trial, and Systematic Review" to exclude general reviews and limit the number of search hits.

citations.NLM: Bailey CJ, Gwilt M. Diabetes, Metformin and the Clinical Course of Covid-19: Outcomes, Mechanisms and Suggestions on the Therapeutic Use of Metformin Front Pharmacol. 2022;13():784459. PMID: 35370738
citations.BibTeX: @article{35370738, title={Diabetes, Metformin and the Clinical Course of Covid-19: Outcomes, Mechanisms and Suggestions on the Therapeutic Use of Metformin}, author={Bailey CJ and Gwilt M}, journal={Front Pharmacol}, volume={13}, pages={784459}}

results.title: Promising translatable pharmacological interventions for body weight management in individuals with severe mental illness - a narrative review.
results.text_hl: AREAS COVERED: A literature search was conducted including agents approved for the management of @DISEASE_Obesity @DISEASE_MESH:D009765 @@@obesity@@@ in the general population, along with upcoming agents under investigation in phase III trials with @DISEASE_Weight_Loss @DISEASE_MESH:D015431 @@@weight loss@@@ properties. EXPERT OPINION: @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@Metformin@@@ and @CHEMICAL_Topiramate @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000077236 @@@topiramate@@@ along with lifestyle interventions are commonly prescribed for @DISEASE_Weight_Gain @DISEASE_MESH:D015430 @@@weight gain@@@ in individuals with @<m>DISEASE_Severe_Acute_Respiratory_Syndrome</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D045169 @@@SMI@@@; however, their @DISEASE_Weight_Loss @DISEASE_MESH:D015431 @@@weight loss@@@ potential is modest at best.

citations.NLM: De R, Prasad F, Stogios N, Burin L, Ebdrup BH, Knop FK, Hahn MK, Agarwal SM. Promising translatable pharmacological interventions for body weight management in individuals with severe mental illness - a narrative review. Expert Opin Pharmacother. 2023 Aug 31;():. PMID: 37653675
citations.BibTeX: @article{37653675, title={Promising translatable pharmacological interventions for body weight management in individuals with severe mental illness - a narrative review.}, author={De R and Prasad F and Stogios N and Burin L and Ebdrup BH and Knop FK and Hahn MK and Agarwal SM}, journal={Expert Opin Pharmacother}}

results.title: Long-term changes in carbohydrate tolerance, insulin secretion and action in African-American patients with obesity and history of hyperglycemic crises
results.text_hl: Seventy-five participants with @DISEASE_Diabetic_Ketoacidosis @DISEASE_MESH:D016883 @@@DKA@@@ (n=33) and @<m>DISEASE_Severe_Acute_Respiratory_Syndrome</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D045169 @@@SH@@@ (n=42) underwent 2-hour 75 g oral @CHEMICAL_Glucose @CHEMICAL_MESH:D005947 @@@glucose@@@ tolerance test (OGTT) after @GENE_INS @GENE_3630 @@@insulin@@@ discontinuation and every 6 months until @DISEASE_Hyperglycemia @DISEASE_MESH:D006943 @@@hyperglycemia@@@ relapse (FBG >=130 mg/dL, HbA1c >7% or two random BG >=180 mg/dL) while treated with @DISEASE_Dyskinesias @DISEASE_MESH:D020820 @@@OAD@@@ (@<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@, @CHEMICAL_Sitagliptin_Phosphate @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000068900 @@@sitagliptin@@@ or @CHEMICAL_Pioglitazone @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000077205 @@@pioglitazone@@@) or placebo.

citations.NLM: Vellanki P, Stefanovski D, Anzola II, Smiley DD, Peng L, Umpierrez GE. Long-term changes in carbohydrate tolerance, insulin secretion and action in African-American patients with obesity and history of hyperglycemic crises BMJ Open Diabetes Res Care. 2020 May;8(1):. PMID: 32475838
citations.BibTeX: @article{32475838, title={Long-term changes in carbohydrate tolerance, insulin secretion and action in African-American patients with obesity and history of hyperglycemic crises}, author={Vellanki P and Stefanovski D and Anzola II and Smiley DD and Peng L and Umpierrez GE}, journal={BMJ Open Diabetes Res Care}, volume={8}, number={1}}

results.title: Pharmacological management of diabetes in severe mental illness: a comprehensive clinical review of efficacy, safety and tolerability.
results.text_hl: The first line therapeutic option for @DISEASE_Diabetes_Mellitus_Type_2 @DISEASE_MESH:D003924 @@@T2DM@@@ in @<m>DISEASE_Severe_Acute_Respiratory_Syndrome</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D045169 @@@SMI@@@ for which there is most evidence is @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@.

citations.NLM: Lally J, O' Loughlin A, Stubbs B, Guerandel A, O'Shea D, Gaughran F. Pharmacological management of diabetes in severe mental illness: a comprehensive clinical review of efficacy, safety and tolerability. Expert Rev Clin Pharmacol. 2018 Apr;11(4):411-424. PMID: 29480037
citations.BibTeX: @article{29480037, title={Pharmacological management of diabetes in severe mental illness: a comprehensive clinical review of efficacy, safety and tolerability.}, author={Lally J and O' Loughlin A and Stubbs B and Guerandel A and O'Shea D and Gaughran F}, journal={Expert Rev Clin Pharmacol}, volume={11}, number={4}, pages={411-424}}

results.title: Effectiveness of Pharmacologic Interventions in the Management of Weight Gain in Patients With Severe Mental Illness: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.
results.text_hl: CONCLUSIONS: @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@Metformin@@@ and @CHEMICAL_Topiramate @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000077236 @@@topiramate@@@ were the most-studied agents for weight control in @<m>DISEASE_Severe_Acute_Respiratory_Syndrome</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D045169 @@@SMI@@@ and were considered efficacious and safe in promoting weight reduction compared to placebo in this population.

citations.NLM: Hiluy JC, Nazar BP, Gonçalves WS, Coutinho W, Appolinario JC. Effectiveness of Pharmacologic Interventions in the Management of Weight Gain in Patients With Severe Mental Illness: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Prim Care Companion CNS Disord. 2019 Dec 19;21(6):. PMID: 31856432
citations.BibTeX: @article{31856432, title={Effectiveness of Pharmacologic Interventions in the Management of Weight Gain in Patients With Severe Mental Illness: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.}, author={Hiluy JC and Nazar BP and Gonçalves WS and Coutinho W and Appolinario JC}, journal={Prim Care Companion CNS Disord}, volume={21}, number={6}}
